1591840562|5.0|To say that I really enjoyed reading his book is an understatement. Guy's personality emerges in between the lines as a people person, highly energized, positive and radiating with warmth, all of which I had an opportunity to confirm when we met at the beginning of his lecture held on September 30 at the Global Entrepreneurship Center, Florida International University. <br /> <br />Guy's writing style is a fresh breeze in the sea of books about the subject of entrepreneurship. To begin with, he brings a new meaning to the phrase: reading a book \\"cover to cover\\". The inner -side of the dust jacket feature all the entries to a competition Guy created for the design of his book cover, the art of marketing by itself! <br /> <br />The book is organized into eleven chapters which are grouped in a logical sequence of events: Causation, Articulation, Activation, Proliferation and Obligations. However, Kawasaki goes beyond the trivial route of conventional entrepreneurial wisdom; He discusses the importance of being a \\"Mench\\", Yiddish for a trusted man, in the overall entrepreneurial equation.  <br /> <br />Of special interest to me were three components that were interwoven into the text throughout the book: every chapter begins with the GIST, some kind of a birds view of the subject in the chapter, and ends up with both, a list of FAQ and a short exercise that enables the reader to get instant feedback on the message was understood. It also contains a well documented list of references some of which are already included in my library. Kawasaki ends up the book with a comprehensive and easy to follow index.   <br /> <br />Kawasaki's suggestions are simple to follow; for example, he suggests you send yourself an e-mail and review how it comes across. Another suggestion is the 10-20-30 rules, which refers to presentations before venture capitalists: 10 Power Point slides, 20 minutes and 30 font size. Kawasaki also provides a \\"virtual visit\\" into the VC's world  by providing key clues from his own experience on an array of subjects ranging from how to make a presentation powerful and convincing and how to interpretate the VC's response, to a list of questions and answers that any entrepreneur should keep in mind when dealing with VC firms. <br /> <br />I found it interesting that although the overall focus is on Kawasaki's experience with the high tech industry, many of his ideas and solutions can be easily implemented in other industries, such as the not for profit, for example.  <br /> <br />After I read the book I felt I would welcome a sequel; something along the lines of the \\"Art of the Finish Line\\", or even a more focused book on the  subject of the character traits that are likely to be found in a successful entrepreneur beyond the monetary reward and what it takes to develop them. <br /> <br />If my recommendation was for people to read the book, having met the author, I would strongly encourage organizations to invite him as a guest speaker. He is a talented speaker who knows how to instill passion and excitement in his audiences throughout his presentation by taking them on the entrepreneurial rollercoaster through the eyes of his many years of hard work and experience.  <br /> <br />Doron Zilbershtein <br />
B000268QB2|5.0|I had the opportunity a couple of weeks ago to see the band Keane in concert, and actually got autographs and pictures with the band members afterwards.  But enough about the concert, I want to talk about the music.  Keane's debut album, \\"Hopes and Fears,\\" is one of the most prolific albums of the year.  It is unfortunate, however, that pop fluff like Britney and Hilary dominates the radio, when true talent such as Keane is overlooked. <br /> <br />But I really want to talk about the music.  This whole album signifies the losses that can occur in any type of relationship, whether it be for the good or the bad.  Yes, the album does showcase some uplifting tunes, but for the most part, the album leaves you in a state of longing to start back at the beginning. <br /> <br />Of course, the first single, \\"Somewhere Only We Know,\\" reminds me a lot of the material Wings put out in the 70s (and of course, Tom Chaplin's voice is very reminiscent of Paul McCartney's).  But as the album progresses, you soon come to realize the hurt that can be possible from any type of relationship.  Listen to the seventh track, \\"She Has No Time,\\" and you will be swept away into a drowning sea of loneliness from a woman who no longer has the time to commit to love. <br /> <br />\\"Everybody's Changing\\" is another one of my favorite tracks.  It showcases the mighty talented Tim Rice-Oxley on piano as the track leads you through a person watching as others change while they're staying put.  Richard Hughes is a master at bringing in the right drums for each track, especially on the drum driven \\"Untitled 1.\\" <br /> <br />I recommend this album to anyone who appreciates artists who still write their own music and can perform without the need of a guitarist.  When listening to this album, I was extremely impressed with each track not having a guitar lead, and it keeps me captivated each time I listen to the album. <br /> <br />I only hope this album will be acknowledged by the Grammys in 2005.  I already know Keane is a huge success internationally; Keane can be a huge success in the U.S. as well.  Check this album out, and I'm sure you'll be very pleased!

0385659806|4.0|This is a very unusual novel mostly because of the narrator's autism. Simple to read, the novel has an interesting rhythm to it as the reader becomes more familiar with Christopher's disability. While I initially thought it would become repetitive, the story takes some turns to make it a consistently enjoyable reading experience.<br />Christopher begins to write the book to solve the mystery of the murder of Wellington, a neighbor's dog, like his hero Sherlock Holmes. Along the way, we learn about his family situation, his view of the world, his idiosyncrasies, and his school life. He's not exactly an unreliable narrator, but the author does an excellent job of imagining the problems involved when the storyteller has autism and the story is consistent with this perspective.<br />While not a perfect book, I would recommend this highly, especially to people who want a fresh and different reading experience. It's not at all preachy, and it deals with a little understood disability with honesty; this reader came away from the book with a new understanding of the difficulties of dealing with autism. It is well worth your time to pick this one up

0780622553|5.0|A film drenched in atmosphere, a unique story, wonderful villains, great sets and solid acting: a superb film.<br /><br />Imagine waking up in a bathrub not knowing who you are, why there's a dead woman in the adjacent room, or why mysterious people are chasing you. 0743455967|5.0|Many authors, when asked about their career, are haughty and condescending. They act like it's a gift that no one else could posess, and we the readers are the stupid, pitiful little beings that couldn't possibly begin to comprehend their books, much less write one. Not so with King. No, he doesn't promise a free ride to becoming an author. His book, he will gladly tell you, is not your one-stop solution to all your writing problems. But it IS a start, and an encouraging one at that. The first half of this book is almost totally about his career as a writer, and no less fascinating than any of his other stories, even though this one is nonfiction. He is straightforward and honest, and gives the reader a closer connection to him. The second part of On Writing deals with the title-it's literally \\"on writing\\". Don't be looking for a dry textbook explanation, though. Still incorporating his own experiances and delightful tidbits about the process he has gone through in writing some of his books, such as Carrie, The Stand, and his wonderful Dark Tower series, King goes over all the factors that make up a good story, and what to avoid. I read this book in two days, and in saying that, I'm not saying \\"easy read\\", but \\"wonderful read\\". King had me constantly enthralled, constantly attentive to what he was saying. This is a useful and instructive book, but more than that, this is an inspiring book. It is hopeful and welcoming to new readers, and full of a passion for writing itself. Stephen King doesn't once promise an easy road full of fame and riches to a beginning writer...but he promises it'll be a heck of a trip, and there isn't a thing in the world that could ever compare. Cheers to Stephen King, and a resounding, simple \\"Thanks\\" for all you have written, and all you have shared...and most of all, for how much passion and inspiration you bring into your books and give to your readers. This relatively new Constant Reader has loved the trip so far, and is looking forwardto more of it.
B00006LLNU|4.0|People take Sigur Ros very seriously, maybe beacause of the whole \\"these songs don't really have names\\" thing and the \\"we made up our own language thing\\" but they don't seem to lofty or serious when you really think about it.  This music is somewhat predictable even though it is often beautiful.  The tempos are lumbering and the instrumentation is thick and somewhat unconventional.  It is moody, or just very emotional, but not a terribly eventful or arresting listen.  This band doesn't really need to give the songs names because they can barely be called songs; the two halves of the album kind of run together a little. <br /> <br />The only thing to say here is this stuff isn't complicated, just elegantly presented and very nice to listen to as you are doing something else or if you are just in a very chilled mood.  Basically either you like it or you don't, so just listen to the samples and you will probably have the idea.
B00005JMJG|4.0|This movie is definitely something new; it was produced by Focus Features, which tends to focus on films that are very anti-Hollywood in the sense that they are definitely not for everyone.  This film, along with Lost in Translation (another Focus movie), appeal to certain people, while others may not understand the content or simply find it boring.  This film also requires the viewer to think, which is a trait that many big studio films severely lack lately.<br /><br />The story centers around Joel Barish (Jim Carrey), a quiet introvert who, while constantly making negative observations toward the world, never does anything to better his situation in life.  That is until one day, for no reason at all, he skips out on work and goes to the beach, despite the fact that it's February.  While there, he meets Clementine (Kate Winslet), who is Joel's polar opposite.  She's a free spirit with a bit of a drinking problem, and she and Joel fall in love.  After a messy relationship, Clem decides to have her memories of Joel erased.  Joel finds about this, and, out of a combination of depression and suppressed rage, he decides to have her erased from his memories.  He goes to this clinic run by a Dr. Howard Mierzwiak (Tom Wilkinson) and his unprofessional staff.  While his staffers Stan (Mark Ruffalo), Patrick (Elijah Wood), and Mary (Kirsten Dunst) get drunk, stoned, and naked while working on Joel, he subconsciously decides that he no longer wants to erase her after he is forced to remember all the good memories he made with Clementine.  He then proceeds to \\"hide\\" his mental Clem in other memories where she doesn't belong, which creates some pretty funny results.<br /><br />For such a difficult concept, writer Charlie Kauffman did a very good job keeping things from getting too confusing.  Not only that, but he was also able to create a great twist to the whole thing.<br /><br />As I said earlier, this movie is not for everyone. B0000029GA|5.0|Nas has gotten scattered since Illmatic, but Illmatic is a tight little album.  It is one of the most succinct and well balanced portraits of 90s New York hip hop, as opposed to the worthy but less focused works of Mobb Deep, BIG, etc.  I am not trying to insult those other artists, but say that this album's importance lies in its ability to say its piece (over excellent but basic production and with just the right amount of guest artists) and shut up.  Nas is young here but he sounds world weary, if almost poetic in his almost nihlistic view of life and where it is going.  He is a rapper with a lot to say and a determination to say it; among mainstream veterans he is way up there, maybe a little less of a sellout than Jay Z, maybe not. <br /> <br />But Illmatic is neither spectacular, incredibly unique, nor earth shattering.  There is nothing said here that isn't said elsewhere, so placing this album at the top of \\"best rap albums of all time\\" lists can be excessive.  This work is near the top of a bloated and overrated genre that steals attention from people who preach something besides bleak materialism and capitulation to the hood machinery that keeps eating all america's black people, even though Nas has moved from here since it was released.

B000002LFZ|3.0|Fleetwood Mac \\"Greatest Hits\\" is a collection of 16 songs from the group's peak period.    I would define the \\"peak period\\" as the five studio albums that the band did once Lindsey Buckingham and Stevie Nicks were brought into the band.    The addition of Buckingham and Nicks completed the forming of what was the core lineup for the band.(Lindsey Buckingham, Stevie Nicks, Christine McVie, John McVie, and Mick Fleetwood)  and completed Fleetwood Mac's transformation from a blues/rock band to a pop band.  The five albums: \\"Fleetwood Mac\\" (1975), \\"Rumours\\" (1977), \\"Tusk\\" (1979), \\"Mirage\\" (1982), and \\"Tango in the Night\\" (1987).    In a lot of ways, this was a culmination of the work done by these four members.  Following the release of \\"Tango in the Night\\", Lindsey Buckingham - who was a major creative force in Fleetwood Mac would depart the band.   Fleetwood Mac decided to replace Buckingham with 2 new members - vocalist Billy Burnette and guitarist Rick Vito.   So while this may be a culmination of what the core members would do, it also would be an introduction to the next era of Fleetwood Mac as the new lineup contributes two songs.   In addition to these two songs, there are 14 songs from the 5 albums made by the core members. <br /> <br />At the time \\"Greatest Hits\\" was released, Fleetwood Mac had a lot of momentum going.   Following the release of 1982's \\"Mirage\\" (which still failed to recapture a lot of the magic that 1977's \\"Rumours\\" had), Fleetwood Mac went on hiatus for 5 years until \\"Tango in the Night\\" was released.  Once \\"Tango\\" was released, the band had a lot of momentum going - easily the most since \\"Rumours\\".   Despite Buckingham's departure, the band continued the momentum from \\"Tango\\" as they went on a World Tour.  Thus it seemed the perfect time for a greatest hits collection to be released - and the perfect stage to introduce the new members. <br /> <br />As mentioned above, \\"Greatest Hits\\" includes 14 old songs and 2 new songs.   The collection does a decent job at distributing the songs: \\"Fleetwood Mac\\" has three songs (\\"Rhiannon\\", \\"Say You Love Me\\",\\"Over My Head\\"); \\"Rumours\\" is represented by the 4 big hits (\\"Don't Stop\\", \\"Go Your Own Way\\", \\"You Make Loving Fun\\", \\"Dreams\\"); Tusk has 2 songs (\\"Tusk\\" and an extended version of \\"Sara\\");  \\"Mirage\\" has two songs (\\"Hold Me\\" and \\"Gypsy\\"); and \\"Tango in the Night\\" has three songs (\\"Everywhere\\", \\"Little Lies\\", \\"Big Love\\").   The one thing to note is that at the time -this was a pretty good way to get all of Fleetwood Mac's \\"hits\\" on one CD.  Like many greatest hit collections, they don't often stand the test of time.  This collection is dated.   All of the songs on this collection (including the 2 'new' tracks) are represented on a newer 2 CD collection called \\"The Very Best of Fleetwood Mac\\" (the only exception is that \\"Big Love\\" is done live).   In addition, 13 of the 14 old songs found on this album are represented in the original or alternate versions on the \\"The Chain\\" boxed set. <br /> <br />The new songs aren't bad - they aren't the best songs I've heard Fleetwood Mac do, but they still aren't bad.   One thing that disappoints me is that Fleetwood Mac got very conservative with having two songs sung by Christine McVie (\\"As Long as You Follow\\") and Stevie Nicks (\\"No Questions Asked\\").   It would have been nice to introduce Billy Burnette's vocals to the fan base  I heard Burnette sing on the \\"Tango\\" Tour and while he isn't Lindsey Buckingham, he still has a lot to offer.   \\"As Long as You Follow\\" is a very average soft song - it fit perfectly in 80s radio.   New Mac member Rick Vito does a nice job on guitar.  I wouldn't buy this CD just to get this song.   I think the better of the two songs is \\"No Questions Asked\\".   Billy Burnette's background vocals are more prominent in this song. This song is a much more uptempo song - also very much cut in the mold for 80s radio.   I was surprised that this song didn't get a lot of airplay in the U.S.  <br /> <br />Asfor the 14 old songs, one thing that I am not happy with is the ordering.   I find that the best \\"Greatest Hits\\" collections are ones that arrange the songs in chronological order.  This allows me to see how the band progresses over time.   \\"Greatest Hits\\" shuffles the order up quite a bit.  There doesn't even seem to be any logic to how the songs were arranged.   \\"Big Love\\" and \\"Over My Head\\" are the last two old songs before the finale - \\"No Questions Asked\\".   This isn't the way to wrap up a greatest hits collection.     <br /> <br />Of course you can make the argument that there are better Fleetwood Mac songs that weren't necessarily \\"hits\\" that are excluded from this collection.   Most notably missing are tunes such as \\"Gold Dust Woman\\", \\"Seven Wonders\\", \\"Landslide\\", and \\"Love in Store\\" (all four are included on \\"The Very Best of Fleetwood Mac set\\").  Then again - you still get 16 songs and back in 1988 that was a good number of songs to get on any single disc collection. <br /> <br />The liner notes do not include any lyrics for these songs - even the new songs do not have the lyrics included.   I'm also disappointed that they don't list what album each of the songs is from.  There are also no songwriting credits, but the production credits are listed.   There is a nice from Stephen Davis that looks at the band on the eve of a concert from the \\"Tango\\" tour - but also provides some insight into each of the band members.  While this collection has good music, but it still is pretty dated and you are better off with \\"The Very Best of Fleetwood Mac\\".  However, you still may want to get this if you can get this CD at a good price.

B00030590I|4.0|*Hero* beautifully-filmed movie turned out to be one of the finer cinematic experiences I've subjected myself to in the last year. This is a state-sanctioned tale manages to more-or-less successfully fuse mythic history with post-modern storytelling in a manner that is occasionally jarring, but generally effective.<br /><br />The plot itself is archetypal in its streamlined straightforwardness: a tyrant warlord has long feared three assassins, but one nameless hero from a little-known province has bested them one after another. By way of rewarding the industrious official and satisfying his own curiosity, the emperor invites the champion to court to tell his tale. The champion's stories comprise the bulk of the movie -- leaving the court visit to serve primarily as a loose frame for the majority of the narrative.<br /><br />And here's where it gets tricky.<br /><br />The hero episodically relates the circumstances of his three victories; and then the emperor -- having listened politely throughout the exposition -- decides that the hero is lying, and that he must be in cahoots with the assassins. Then the warlord proceeds to offer his own speculative version of the three victories. And THEN the hero counters the charge ... offering yet a THIRD version of the three victories which may or may not be the \\"real\\" way things went down. When I accused Hero of being a bit post-modern in its storytelling, this is what I meant: the device of the unreliable narrator is exploited to the fullest.<br /><br />The third and final description of events comes across as the one most likely to be true. For one thing, the hero's final words on the subject are never challenged by the warlord king ... and for another, all the symbolism points our subconscious Magic Eight Balls towards \\"Yes.\\" The actors are finally wearing white, implying that this version is the pure one; and there is a brief out-of-frame tie-in with the court events as we understand them.<br /><br />All in all, I give the movie an A+ for style and a B for story. It wasn't perfect, and I have no doubt that the cultural disconnect between me and China stands in the way of potential deeper appreciation on my part, and that's fine. I got what I wanted from this movie, and I am comfortable recommending it to others.ry. It wasn't perfect, and I have no doubt that the cultural disconnect between me and China stands in the way of potential deeper appreciation on my part, and that's fine. I got what I wanted from this movie, and I am comfortable recommending it to others.

B0002VKZL6|3.0|There is an elegance and strong sense of place in most of these songs and this is what Mr. Knopfler has been shooting for, it seems, since that latter days of Dire Straits. I'm not sure which movie you were watching.<br /><br />I loved this movie.  Loved it, loved it, loved it. Whatever.<br /><br />I go to movies to be entertained, plain and simple. But if you're afraid of being taken over by all that \\"environmentalist BS\\" this movie is supposedly spewing, perhaps you'd be better off taking in another Care Bears feature.<br /><br />I love those darling huggables. 0553213105|3.0|I recently read Pride and Prejudice, by Jane Austen, for a project in my AP English Class. I enjoyed the novel, and thought it fairly funny. The novel begins with Mrs. Bennet, who is earnestly searching husbands for her two eldest daughters, Jane and Elizabeth. The arrival of Charles Bingley, a wealthy bachelor, is an exciting prospect. She thus proceeds to set her daughter Jane up with him, and in the course of events, her other daughter, Elizabeth, falls in love with Mr. Bingley's friend, Fitzwilliam Darcy. The novel seems to lack; however, a more serious plot. The main themes are love, public status, and class, all of which seem to me rather less important in the scheme of things. All throughout the novel, the reader's main motivation to finish the novel is the unveiling of the fate of Elizabeth and Darcy. While the characters are very interesting and well structured, I feel the novel lacks a serious plot line. I believe the novel to be more of a gossip based story rather than a classic. I would not recommend this novel to others.

0393035158|5.0|In our current society it is the height of impropriety to question a person's beliefs which stem from their religious faith. Faith is the bedrock upon which religion is built. Yet The Oxford Dictionary defines faith as: \\"firm belief in something for which there is no proof.\\" For a belief to be rational, it must be supported by proof - or at least a reasoned argument. It follows that those religious laws which seek their justification in faith alone (rather than the law's impact) actually provide no rational basis for why such laws should be enforced.  <br /> <br />But consider, isn't it better to enact laws and form beliefs based upon external justification rather than blind faith? <br /> <br />A case in point: contrast the following religious laws: \\"Thou shall not kill\\" and \\"Don't eat pork.\\" One can find a number of external justifications for not killing people that are not based on faith. For instance: 1) a society in which killing is unchecked would be an impossible place to live, 2) it is ethically, morally, and pragmatically better to treat others they way you would like to be treated, 3) life is precious and should not be wasted, etc. No appeal to faith is necessary to justify \\"thou shall not kill.\\" <br /> <br />\\"Don't eat pork\\" is a little different. Perhaps justification can be found for the prohibition by showing the health hazards of eating pork, but the law is usually justified on the grounds of faith. A holy book has proscribed the conduct, so to engage in the behavior is breaking the rules. No external justification is needed since one accepts the wisdom of the holy book on faith.  <br /> <br />But unfortunately the problems of faith aren't restricted to who eats a ham sandwich and who sticks with the tuna salad. Those who act only on faith without regard to the consequences of their actions are responsible for the crusades, the pogroms, and 9/11. They burn books without reading them and gang rape woman in northern Pakistan. All with the same unquestioned and reliance on faith.  <br /> <br />One reviewer, below, writes \\"Belief in God, not just religion, can make this world a better place.\\" The problem is that Al Qaeda operatives also believe in God... they just think He wants them to fight a holy war rather than to \\"turn the other cheek.\\" Like Christians and their Bible, Al Qaeda can point to passages in the Quraan which support their beliefs. Since God usually doesn't come down to give press conferences to clarify what He actually said, there is no way to convince someone that their faith is wrong and yours is right.  <br /> <br />Faith may be appropriate when it comes to your own relationship with the world, but when you use it as a justification to regulate others, faith is subject to too much abuse. <br />The only effective way to make laws, run governments, or protect societies is to build on a foundation of rational justification.  <br /> <br />This book is an important step in creating a dialogue in this largely-ignored, yet hugely critical force behind today's global politics. <br />

0441009425|4.0|This is a very engrossing novel that is full of interesting, if at times implausible, plot twists.  The witty dialogue is also fun.  Near the end, however, things become progressively more implausible and that mars an otherwise great read.  Alastair Reynolds also has the annoying habit of having characters divulge information to other characters without explaining it to the reader.  A typical example might be something like:  Then XX recounted what she had learned in the Shroud, and YY understood why ZZ had to be stopped at all costs.  At this point, Reynolds then moves onto another character/plot line without recounting XX's narrative.  This happens 3-4 times in the book.  Annoying.  Oh well, nothing's perfect.  Bottom line:  I read it, couldn't put it down, and plan to read the next one!

Worst case scenario, that Bush again gets to set about destroying the world for four more years, at least Mr. Moore will have opened the eyes of millions and millions of people worldwide, and the seeds of peace and truth will have been planted to come to fruition at a slightly later time.  In addition to wholeheartedly recommending this movie, I also highly suggest paying regular visits to michaelmoore.com (especially the MUST READ section) to get more truth coming out every day that the media, influenced too much by the right wing agenda likes to keep hidden.  Bravo Mr. Moore - you have our full support, appreciation and love for all you've done and continue to do.

0060090383|5.0|Serious and funny in equal measure, this book is a perfect read for every woman.  Rachel, as some other reviewers have complained, is indeed a very shallow person whose life is way off track, but this (in case the aforementioned reviewers have somehow missed it) is the story of her RECOVERY.  And what a story!   <br /> <br />Rachel, for those of you who haven't read the plot summaries, is a drug addict living crazy in the big city, and she's finally been convinced to go to rehab...but she's not convinced she's got a problem.  Instead, she sees rehab as a way to meet celebrities and figure out a way to get back her boyfriend, who dumped her when he couldn't handle her drug problem anymore.  She scoffs at the weaknesses of the other addicts, refusing to admit her own, and bitches constantly about her terrifying therapist, awful roommate, and total lack of celebrity sightings.   <br /> <br />While we're laughing (or shaking our heads) at how snippy and silly and immature Rachel can be, somehow Ms. Keyes gets us inside her head and we begin to understand her, just as Rachel begins to understand herself.  Then the healing begins, and boy is the journey painful.  With great sensitivity and without overanalyzing, Ms. Keyes gives us an unflinching look at addiction, adulthood, love, sex, confronting the self, and healing it.  A gifted writer by whom I have not read a bad book, Marian Keyes has outdone herself with RACHEL'S HOLIDAY. <br /> <br />One complaint (not M.K.'s fault): the cover.  Where do they keep coming up with these stupid covers full of people way too skinny to be serious, let alone real?  For all its humor, this is ultimately a serious story of personal redemption, and for that the cover is completely wrong.

B00005JKGO|5.0|Although many argue about the meaning of his films, few will debate Fellini's impact on cinema and popular culture. I find it amusing how many people try to find a moral message in his films and characters. The brilliance of his films is that characters  are presented without sympathy or scorn. They simply exist like fleeting emotions. Sure, you'll love, envy and hate Marcello's character all at the same time. That's a lot like real life. Feminists always hate Fellini's portrayal of women as sex objects. Get a critical life! The same director who gave us La Dolce Vita and 8 1/2 turned around and made a brilliant film about a middle aged woman's point of view in \\"Juliette of the Spirits\\".<br /><br />Returning to la Dolce Vita, Fellini seems as obsessed as we are with the celebrity lifestyle and glitz of the famous. This film is oddly prescient in predicting that mania for the rich and famous. I'll go out on a limb here and say that fans of Reality TV Shows will find La Dolce Vita oddly familiar. Let's not forget the strange photographer who hangs around Marcello named \\"Paparazzo\\". This cinematic leech is precisely where the term \\"Paparazzi\\" comes from... Fellini foresaw that bizarre pop culture vulture would be increasingly a participant in celebrity lives (and deaths) as well as a chronicler.<br /><br />In spite of all this, Fellini's films are fun. He seems to have the unique ability to breezily make biting social commentary, while at the same time showing us all the decadent fun we want. Perhaps the final word is that Life is Sweet, no matter how screwed up it is. Like this film, the best thing is to just jump in and experience it.

B0000524CY|4.0|For starters, the extended version of this film is no improvement on the original version of \\"The Exorcist\\" nor does it hurt it.  The additions are just redundant. Forget the more sensational aspects of the film(the head-turning, the projectile vomiting, the over-the-top obsenity)where this film scares most is on a psycholological level.  The film takes pains to explain the psychological and theological aspects of satanic possession.  The mood of the film is enhanced by great cinematography, particularly it's chilly, damp Georgetown setting.  No film that I can recall has utilized sound to elicit chills like this one does.  There is a superb cast here led by Ellen Burstyn as the distraught mother, Chris MacNeil.  Central to the film is Jason Miller's performance as Father Damien Karras, a church psychologist who is experiencing doubt in his chosen calling.  It is this character that adds heft to most of the film.  Max Von Sydow is effectively authorative as Father Merrin, the priest who had encountered satanic possession before and was almost killed by the experience.  It's difficult to gauge the contribution of Linda Blair because of her age I believe doubles were utilized for the more intense sequences her character, Regan, was in.  For instance, actress Mercedes McCambridge contributed the voice of Regan in the latter stages of possession.

B000000HZT|5.0|Genesis keyboardist Tony Banks began his solo career with 1979's \\"A Curious Feeling.\\" This is an outstanding solo debut for Banks, and, of all his solo albums, \\"A Curious Feeling\\" is the most progressive-sounding, the one that sounds the most like vintage Genesis. Not only is Tony's songwriting and keyboard-playing here superb (as always), but he also proves himself on this album to be a fine guitarist and bass player. With some extra help from Genesis' touring drummer Chester Thompson and singer Kim Beacon, Tony delivers such stunning tracks as the instrumentals \\"From The Undertow,\\" \\"Forever Morning,\\" and the truly gorgeous \\"Waters Of Lethe,\\" as well as great melodic songs like \\"Lucky Me\\" (which *could* have been a hit single), and the title tune. There's also brilliant progressive tracks like the powerful \\"Somebody Else's Dream,\\" and, what is arguably the album's centerpiece, \\"You,\\" which starts off as a beautiful love song before seguing into a charging, classic Genesis-style instrumental break. Brilliant music, and brilliant performances all around by Banks, Thompson and singer Kim Beacon, whose powerful voice fits Tony's dramatic rock perfectly. \\"A Curious Feeling\\" is a terrific solo debut for Tony Banks.
0790729628|5.0|Not to dismiss the director's cut of \\"Blade Runner\\", but I have a soft spot for the version I saw in the theatre during the Summer of '82 with it's studio imposed narration and happy ending.  When I saw this film then I was just blown away.  Bear in mind, though, that it was released in the summer of \\"E.T.\\" when the audiences were more inclined toward feel-good alien movies and not somber futuristic sci-fi.  The reviews at the time said it was more style than substance, and the box office was lukewarm.  The fortunes of \\"Blade Runner\\" were revived with the emerging home video market(Another classic futuristic film was released that summer, \\"The Road Warrior\\").  Why is this film a classic in either version?  The sets and special effects in this film are just mind-blowing.  It imagines Los Angeles in the year 2020 where hi-tech mingles with decay, where the cultural influences are hybrid Anglo-Mexican-Japanese, and there has been an ecological change in weather patterns where sunny California now more closely resembles Seattle.  The plot involves a group of replicants(androids) with a built-in limited lifespan who escape slave labor in the off-world colonies who return to Earth to find their creator to increase their life expectancy.  Since replicants are outlawed on Earth it is the job of blade runners(bounty hunters) to exterminate them, Deckard (Harrison Ford) being most prominent among blade runners.  Ford gives an appropriately world weary performance as Deckard, something akin to a detective from a Chandler or Hammet novel.  Rutger Hauer as Roy Batty, the leader of the replicants, gives a multi-leveled performance where we are simultaneous sympathetic to his plight but repulsed by the apparent barbarity of his actions in carrying out his goal.  Sean Young is beautiful and mysterious as Rachel, like a femme fatale from a 40's noir film.  A young Darryl Hannah is also quite good as Pris, one of the replicants.  I'd also like to note the presence of Joe Turkel who plays Tyrell, head of the corporation who created the replicants.  Turkel was a veteran of Stanley Kubrick films, specifically \\"Paths of Glory\\" and \\"The Shining\\".  \\"Blade Runner\\" is a great film in either it's original version and the director's cut.  My only question is what is the meaning of the unicorn dream?

B00005JNBQ|5.0|The summer movie season is gone and with it came the usual onslaught of action flicks, big-budget thrillers and even a few hilarious comedies. Matt Damon, Will Smith, Tom Cruise, Tobey Maguire and Will Ferrell all had big hits. However, in the midst of all the robots, amnesiac hit men, mustachioed newscasters and web slinging, a different kind of leading man set quite a unique landmark: Filmdom has a new reigning nerd, and his name is Napoleon Dynamite.<br /><br />Newcomer Jon Heder stars as the protagonist in the title role of director Jared Hess' debut film about a tall, moon boot-wearing geek with thick glasses and a curly red hairdo trying to make it through his high school days in rural Idaho. He lives with his older brother Kip (Aaron Ruell), an equally clueless loser who spends his days chatting with babes on the Internet, and their grandmother, a four-wheeler enthusiast played by Sandy Martin.<br /><br />After an accident in the sand dunes leaves granny with a broken coccyx, Napoleon and Kip's uncle Rico (Jon Gries) becomes their temporary caretaker. Uncle Rico assumes this responsibility the only way he knows how: by showing the boys boring videos of himself throwing footballs past the camera (his team almost won State in 1982) and recruiting Kip to help him sell plastic kitchenware and breast enlargement pills door-to-door.<br /><br />In between receiving nonstop ridicule and alienation from his classmates, Napoleon spends most of his spare time touting his nunchaku skills, drawing flatulent fantasy creatures, feeding his pet llama Tina scraps of ham, sloppily chugging cranberry juice, testing out a time machine Kip bought online (complete with power crystals) and learning \\"flippin' sweet moves\\" from an ancient hip-hop dance tape he finds at a thrift store.<br /><br />Rest assured, \\"Napoleon Dynamite\\" does have a plot, minimal as it may be. He befriends Mexican transfer student Pedro (Efren Ramirez) and manages his campaign to run for class president against the token popular girl Summer (played by Hillary Duff's sister, Haylie). There's even a love interest for Napoleon named Deb (Tina Majorino), a quirky girl who wears a ponytail on the side of her head and specializes in Glamour Shots photography and making cheap vinyl key chains.<br /><br />You'll be too busy, however, watching Heder steal every single scene he's in while at the same time, destroying all the clich&eacute;s of how characters like him are supposed to act. After all, any movie nerd can have a pocket protector and fawn over Gillian Anderson, but how many have ever stuffed tater tots in their pocket or tied fishing line to an action figure and dragged it from a moving school bus? Add to that Heder's throaty, deadpan delivery of lines like \\"Are you drinking 1 percent milk because you think you're fat?\\" and what you end up with is a new cinematic hero for the Star Trek-quoting, comic book-collecting masses.<br /><br />Hess' directorial style and dialogue have drawn comparisons to both Wes Anderson's \\"Rushmore\\" and Todd Solondz's \\"Welcome to the Dollhouse.\\" But his film has indie cred coming from almost every angle and just enough slapstick (including a hilarious cameo by Diedrich Bader as the instructor of his own brand of martial arts, Rex Kwon Do) to distance itself as an extremely original and entertaining movie.<br /><br />If you want to see this hidden gem of a movie (and I highly recommend you do) you'd better hurry because it's likely to be knocked out of theaters soon by the slew of upcoming blockbusters that, most likely, won't contain any tater tots or llamas.o run for class president against the token popular girl Summer (played by Hillary Duff's sister, Haylie). B000006NPY|5.0|In June 1998, the Smashing Pumpkins released their incredible album, \\"Adore\\", which opened up a new pathway for their music.  This was exactly one month before they played a free concert for a lucky 125,000 fans in Minneapolis!<br /><br />Coming down off of the opus of their career, \\"Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness\\", the Smashing Pumpkins wanted to re-direct their musical energy.  Previously, they were knee-deep in the grunge hoopla, focusing on driving, gritty guitars and screaming vocals.  On \\"Adore\\", they evolved into a more melodic down tempo which was not as well-received as their former albums.  The guitar buzzing was still around on tracks like \\"Ava Adore\\", but much of the album had a very heavy piano thread and at times, an electronica background, to which fans were generally not as receptive.  If you have never heard this album or if you would just like to see if your opinions match the ones below, (on a scale of 1 to 10), then read on!<br /><br />\\"Adore\\" is one of those excellently gloomy records that you can listen to while watching the rain out your window, or while you're going through something rough in your life, or to just simply appreciate the beauty in the lyrics and musical accompaniment that Billy Corgan and co. expertly craft together, which ultimately feels like you are reading through a chest of letters that Corgan left behind for a former love.  Corgan has stated that he wanted this album to be an enigma, not a Pumpkins record, not an acoustic record and not an electronica record, something indescribable.  This is a concept to be appreciated and one that you can feel that in every track on this heart-breaking record.<br /><br />Track 1: To Sheila--(9)--Starting with the opening track, you know you are not listening to a typical Smashing Pumpkins record.  Corgan's voice is crisp, clear and melodic and doesn't have the normal razor-sharp edge to it.  You can understand the lyrics clearly and really feel within you the emotions being conveyed here.  The instrumental accompaniment is light and soft as well.<br /><br />Track 2: Ava Adore--(10)--one of the singles from this album, this is a strong track.  Here, the Pumpkins pick up the tempo a bit as Corgan wails about his obsession and desire for his love.  She is everything in his world, from the beauty to the murder, and he will do everything he can to keep them together and keep her perfect for him.<br /><br />Track 3: Perfect--(9)--the companion and follow-up to their classic \\"1979\\", Corgan is telling a former love that things can be perfect this time around if they can just give it another go.  This was released as a follow-up single, but did not do as well as \\"Ava Adore\\", which ultimately lead to the back-burner positioning of this album.<br /><br />Track 4: Daphne Descends--(8)--a good track with a great beat, Corgan is calling a girl out on her love for someone who will never return it.  She loves him for herself, he will never love her back, or at least, not in the same way that she loves him.<br /><br />Track 5: Once Upon a Time--(7)--a song from Corgan to his mother, he's trying to tell her that he's not doing as well with his life as he had hoped, but he will lie to her so she remains proud of him.  He misses her and wants to let her know, without directly letting her know, that he's miserable at times without her.<br /><br />Track 6: Tear--(7)--Corgan is coping with the death of a loved one.  He blames heaven for taking them away and is bitter that she can now laugh with the light while he licks his wounds in the darkness.<br /><br />Track 7: Crestfallen--(10)--This song is stunningly beautiful.  Corgan has someone in his past that he needs to re-connect with now.  They have left him but he knows they can't fully be gone because of all the memories they built together in all of the time they spent together.  He feels he doesn't deserve love and sympathy but he would love another chance with this person to prove that notion wrong.<br /><br/>Track 8: Appels + Oranjes--(6)--what if everything as you knew it ceased to exist in the way you knew it to be so?  What if you weren't the person you thought you were?  Would you choose to be something new?<br /><br />Track 9: Pug--(8)--a deeply sensual song, Corgan wants to go home with someone and spend a warm night with them, wrapped up in them, whispering sweet secrets or draining the desire from him, just being with him and being warm and desired.<br /><br />Track 10: The Tale of Dusty and Pistol Pete--(7)--a gritty, rough tale of a love gone wrong between Dusty and Pistol Pete.<br /><br />Track 11: Annie-Dog--(8)--in a battle with amphetamines, Corgan asks if it's so bad to let her take him under, into peace, knowing all that he does about the evil she can do?<br /><br />Track 12: Shame--(8)--you know you shouldn't let them get to you, you know you shouldn't question yourself, but despite all that, you're still going to feel ashamed.<br /><br />Track 13: Behold!  The Night Mare--(8)--Corgan has been trying so hard to make her happy, but he can't go on digging roses from her grave.  He knows the inevitable, that this is going to end, and he is trying to accept that all of his efforts have gone wasted.<br /><br />Track 14: For Martha--(8)--it's time for her to go, to cross over to the other side, and he will see her there.  He tells her not to cry or say goodbye because he'll be okay.  We are all in mourning for our true home since the day we are born, so he has accepted that she needs to return \\"home\\".<br /><br />Track 15: Blank Page--(9)--Corgan is coping with a lost love in this heartbreaking song.  He is miserable, he can't sleep, and he's tired of his friends offering their sympathies on the phone.  He even tortures himself further by going to look for her at the five and dime store.  He tells her to plant some trees to shade her from him and to let her children play beneath, which is quite possibly one of the saddest lines on the album.<br /><br />Track 16: 17--(6)--17 seconds of piano music, a pleasant and quiet end to such an emotionally outpouring album.exist in the way you knew it to be so?  What if you weren't the person you thought you were?  Would you choose to be something new?    Track 9: Pug--(8)--a deeply sensual song, Corgan wants to go home with someone and spend a warm night with them, wrapped up in them, whispering sweet secrets or draining the desire from him, just being with him and being warm and desired.    Track 10: The Tale of Dusty and Pistol Pete--(7)--a gritty, rough tale of a love gone wrong between Dusty and Pistol Pete.     Track 11: Annie-Dog--(8)--in a battle with amphetamines, Corgan asks if it's so bad to let her take him under, into peace, knowing all that he does about the evil she can do?    Track 12: Shame--(8)--you know you shouldn't let them get to you, you know you shouldn't question yourself, but despite all that, you're still going to feel ashamed.    Track 13: Behold!  The Night Mare--(8)--Corgan has been trying so hard to make her happy, but he can't go on digging roses from her grave.  He knows the inevitable, that this is going to end, and he is trying to accept that all of his efforts have gone wasted.    Track 14: For Martha--(8)--it's time for her to go, to cross over to the other side, and he will see her there.  He tells her not to cry or say goodbye because he'll be okay.  We are all in mourning for our true home since the day we are born, so he has accepted that she needs to return \\"home\\".    Track 15: Blank Page--(9)--Corgan is coping with a lost love in this heartbreaking song.  He is miserable, he can't sleep, and he's tired of his friends offering their sympathies on the phone.  He even tortures himself further by going to look for her at the five and dime store.  He tells her to plant some trees to shade her from him and to let her children play beneath, which is quite possibly one of the saddest lines on the album.    Track 16: 17--(6)--17 seconds of piano music, a pleasant and quiet end to such an emotionally outpouring album.

B000003S0D|3.0|This is a very, very strange album - heavily avant-jazz-influenced and utterly impenetrable at turns, but never boring, and great in many places. Of course, Peter Sinfield's lyrics are laughably terrible, and add to the complete pomposity that infects the proceedings (mostly Fripp's). For that matter, Robert Fripp is in remarkably subdued form here on electric guitar, and much of his work is relegated to acoustic guitar and mellotron (which there is a lot of). Many times, he just strums along and lets the session players jam - for this is what it amounts to; many of the players here were associates of Keith Tippet, and the master pianist himself is featured quite heavily on this album on piano and electric piano. The \\"band\\", as such, pretty much quit right after the album, the musicians being Gordon Haskell on vocals and bass, Andy McCulloch on drums, and Mel Collins on saxes and flutes. Haskell and McCulloch dumped Fripp after this album, which serves him right, because both did very well on this album. McCulloch, who later drummed for Greenslade, incorporates elements of many styles within his drumming (to me, at least, it sounds like he gets a little funky on a bit of \\"Cirkus\\", besides all the obvious jazz influence), and Haskell sings very well and plays very melodic, picked bass, quite McCartney-influenced. \\"Cirkus\\" starts proceedings off well, with a ridiculously menacing Mellotron riff, and becomes a classic and totally pretentious epic, with hilariously stupid lyrics from Sinfield - I love the moment in the song when everything cuts out and the Mellotrons create such a wacky fake-string sound, before it all builds up again, with another wacky psuedo-classical guitar solo. \\"Indoor Games\\" isn't all that good, but \\"Happy Family\\" is just about the craziest song that the early incarnation ever pulled out of its' catalog, with wild electric piano runs from Tippet, jazzy rhythm and occasionally atonal lead guitar from Fripp (which sounds quite like Tippet's electric piano), heavily tremoloed Mellotron also from Fripp, saddened flute from Collins, honking trombone from Nick Evans, multifaceted drumming from McCulloch, and fantastic bass from Haskell. The most commented-upon feature of the song, aside from it's craziness, is Haskell's distorted vocals, fed through a VCS3 synthesizer, which was operated by Sinfield. If you listen to the vocal, you'll hear Sinfield switching through different effects. The first verse features this weird-as-hell echo/tremolo effect that makes Gordon sound like he's singing through a fish tank; the second verse features distortion that makes him sound like an android; the third verse features a weird phased harmonizer effect, and the fourth verse is without effects. The hush of \\"Lady of the Dancing Water\\" contains Haskell's best vocal performance with Crimson, and the \\"Lizard\\" suite is actually where the album truly goes off the rails; after the first section with Jon Anderson's vocals (I wonder how many takes it took for him to sing the lyrics with a straight face - oh, wait; this is Anderson we're talking about, so maybe he thought they needed some zipping up with talk about Siberian khatrus), it turns into an atonal noisefest without much in the way of inspiration. So it is seriously flawed, but rewarding in many ways.
B00005B36H|5.0|Tool's previous albums, namely Undertow and AEnima, were important milestones in progressive metal (if it can be said that Tool fits within a genre), and were certainly important for their time.  Thanks to Undertow, countless bands that attempted to copy Tool's sound sprung up and flooded the airwaves with similar-sounding, trite music.  AEnima was the logical - albeit unprecedented - next step, and few, if any, bands have been able to imitate its sound.  Henceforth, although its influence will be felt for many years to come, it's unlikely that any band will be able to come close to the near-perfection present on Lateralus. <br /> <br />This record is nothing less than a masterpiece.  All tracks are highlights; rating each one individually would be a waste of time.  However, as a fan who has seen Tool (Adam Jones, guitar; Danny Carey, drums; Justin Chancellor, bass; Maynard James Keenan, vocals) replicate these songs live, I can say that the true standouts on this record are \\"The Grudge\\" and the closing 3-part trilogy.  \\"The Grudge\\", as an opening statement, is about as powerful as you could hope for - intense meter shifts, pounding articulation, and overall groove separate it from the pack.  It should be noted that on this song, as on all others, Tool displays an adept touch at manipulating dynamic contrast.  AEnima featured the loud-soft shadings that Nirvana brought to the fore, but Lateralus takes it several steps further.  Dynamics range from pianissimo to triple forte on this record, hitting all stops in between.  These dynamics are most noticeable on \\"The Grudge\\". <br /> <br />From there we get more incredible tracks, including the interesting bass/guitar interplay of \\"Eon Blue Apocalypse\\", and the dirge-like, incredibly dynamically varied (again) pulse of \\"The Patient\\".  Maynard delivers positive and interesting performances, both lyrically and musically, throughout, and this track is no different.  He uses the metaphor of recovering from illness/addiction quite adeptly and somehow the message is supported by the band's playing (a characteristic inherent in all great records).  After \\"The Patient\\", the weird sounds of \\"Mantra\\" segue into \\"Schism\\", which most everyone has probably heard by now, so I won't detail it too much.  It definitely is more radio-friendly than the other songs, but that doesn't diminish its impact. <br /> <br />The first suite, \\"Parabol\\"/\\"Parabola\\", kicks off with a low-in-the-mix guitar figure, echoed by Maynard's soothing, preacher-like mentality.  It builds from there into an epic rock song with more traditional loud-soft dynamics.  This song was also a single and video, so many of you have probably heard it already.  \\"Ticks and Leeches\\" is a conventional (by Tool standards), chops-driven performance with an expansive breakdown in the middle.  It includes pounding drums, loud riffing by guitar and bass, and lots of screaming from Maynard.  The lyrics are probably symbolic, but you can always take visceral comfort in the instrumental attack of Tool's more-than-capable rhythm section. <br /> <br />A stadium-ready guitar riff opens \\"Lateralus\\", the title track on the album, and is joined around a minute later by the fade-in of Carey and Chancellor, who again concoct a furious groove.  This song employs a unique mathematical twist:  The number 987 (a term of the Fibonacci Sequence) is also a motif for the pre-verse:  its time signature cycles through 9/8, 8/8, and 7/8 before repeating.  The \\"spiraling\\" nature of the Fibonacci Sequence, when graphed, was likely an inspiration for the lyrics, which include lines like \\"Spiral out/Keep going\\".  A true epic, this song was the closer on the Lateralus tour, but here is only one highlight among an album full of them. <br /> <br />After \\"Lateralus\\" the real fun starts.  \\"Disposition\\", \\"Reflection\\", and \\"Triad\\" form a connected, 3-part suite that, yes, was performed live on the Lateralus tour.  I will condone from going into an extreme explanation of the trilogy's many parts; rather, I suggest you explore it for yourself (and try to figure out if that really is a violin in \\"Reflection\\").  In this trilogy, beautiful melodies abound, and while the playing of the band is superb, every component of the sound is perfectly balanced, adding even more sonic weight to this 23-minute epic.  Instruments such as tabla, acoustic guitar, violin(?), and sequencer are prominently featured, and lend the piece an ethereal vibe unlike any other.  Needless to say, check it out for yourself.  After the glorious trilogy, \\"Faaip de Oiad\\", which is an excerpt from an Art Bell broadcast set to machinery, closes the set.  It's very strange, but seems right, considering this is a Tool album. <br /> <br />There's not much more I could say about Lateralus that isn't regurgitation of already overdone jubilation over the record.  But it really IS that good.  And like all truly great albums, it only gets better with repeated listenings.  If Tool can top this album, they will be the metal gods of today - if they can't, this album will still serve as their magnum opus of epic proportions, a true artistic statement of unadulerated bliss.  Only time will tell.  And you, dear reader, should run out and experience all of this as soon as possible.

B000002H2H|5.0|Ride the Lightning is truly an amazing effort by James Hetfield, Lars Ulrich, Cliff Burton, Dave Mustaine and the new Kirk Hammett. Mustaine may have left during the Kill 'em All era but that doesn't mean his influence left too, in songs which he made like the title track and 'The Call of Ktulu' he proves that he is 100x better a guitarist than Kirk (although Kirk is amazing too) and Kirk just ended up making more melodic and musically better solos while Dave had the more talented ones. Did I mention Kirk makes his first original solos here? Yeah he does, they sure sound great too even if Daves were better talent-wise. James Hetfields lyrics have matured too, in Kill 'em All he just sang the whole \\"we're a band\\" thing which was annoying as hell, although sometimes he sang about novels but in Ride the Lightning he sings about death, destruction and war (like in the review title). Cliff was always the greatest bassist and on this album, while not as talented as he is on MOP he shines through the instrumental and on the many songs he is credited on. Lars' drumming has also gotten more complex and varied, while on Kill 'em All they were being pounded on like hell. Overall this album is a huge step in maturity than on Kill. <br />   The songs on this album are much better too, especially the structure. Each song has its own signature intro and the best is on 'For Whom the Bell Tolls' which is my personal favorite. Other gold tracks include the title track, 'Fade to Black', 'Fight Fire with Fire', 'The Call of Ktulu' and 'Creeping Death'. Fade to Black is also the bands first ballad, which also makes this album worth more than it already is (which is a lot). It talks about suicide in a first person perspective, it shows just how much of a poet James Hetfield is. <br />I'll rate the songs in order now: <br />Best-For Whom the Bell Tolls A++++++ <br />2nd Best-Ride the Lightning A+ <br />3rd Best-Fade to Black A+ <br />middle-The Call of Ktulu A <br />middle II-Fight Fire with Fire A- <br />3rd Worst-Creeping Death A- <br />2nd Worst-Trapped Under Ice B <br />Worst-Escape D+ <br /> <br />Okay, all in all this is a great album and while not as awesome or melodic as Master of Puppets it should still find a home in any metalheads collection...hell this will belong in even a punk fans collection since I had that when I used to be a Ramones fanatic. Well, just buy it!
0553573403|4.0|Most of the reviews here for this book have nothing but great things to say about the plot. I don't disagree. It's unique, imaginative, well thought out, surprising, and best of all, very entertaining. Martin is a very talented writer. That said, I have a few qualms with this novel. There is a very large amount of characters involved in the story and it takes the author several hundred pages to introduce them all. This 'introduction period' at times can get to feeling a lot like a medievil soap opera due to all of the scene switching  between characters. When all is said and done though, the various interweaving stories come together quite nicely- quite a reward for the reader.<br /><br />My other issue with this book is the overwhelming sexual content. I don't have a problem with characters in a book having sexual relationships with eachother. But it seemed to me that of the author's descriptions of sex acts were present not only to develop the story but to be titilating to the reader.<br /><br />So, if you don't mind reading vivid descriptions of sex acts between grown men and thirteen year old girls (not an exageration) and you want to read a truly original and entertaining fantasy novel, pick this one up.

0345350499|1.0|I am a pagan feminist, and glad to have been raised in the New Age movement by my mother, who counts this as one of her all-time favorites. Not to mention that I've always been fascinated with Celtic mythology and the Arthurian tales, to the point of taking courses in college about them. Should this book, then, not have been right up my alley? Alas, no. BOTH times I have tried to read it, I have ground to a halt because of the dark sickness it makes me feel.  <br /> <br />I tried to read it the first time when I was eighteen, as I was taking a Middle English Romance Epics class at FSU. I loved reading about the Arthurian stories in all their different forms over the centuries, and I thought one with a modern, feminist twist would be ideal. I'd known about Mists for years, had heard my mom and her friends describe it as though it were the definitive strong-spiritual-female story. Instead what I found was a story about women who treated one another and themselves like crap, and whom the author never stopped putting through horrific, hopeless ordeals. I know the story, I know it contains betrayals and tragedy. Most good stories do, because life does. But the relish with which they, and the emotional and physical agony they cause, are described...yuck. I was shocked, upset, almost physically ill by the time I gave up 3/4 way through. And this coming from someone who spent her teen years repeatedly reading, among other things, long Stephen King and Anne Rice novels.  <br /> <br />I tried reading it again this year, at 25, thinking that I may have been too young to see whatever value it obviously has to so many women. Thinking also, that I may have been just going through an emotionally sensitive phase back then, when graphic depictions of agony, cruel disloyalty, and morbid psychological issues might have creeped me out overmuch. I didn't even get halfway through this time. Honestly, I have no idea why anyone finds this inspiring or feminist, it seems the exact oppositeto me. None of the characters are likeable at all, and the women are \\"strong\\" only if \\"strong\\" means \\"manipulative, cruel and hardheaded\\" to you. The honor, courage, and compassion that not only define \\"strength\\" to me, but that have made the Arthurian legends so powerful to so many people over the ages, are utterly absent here. There is a light that's just missing, and what's left is a feeling of claustrophobic brutality, both between the characters, and in the author's treatment of the story. My perception that there is something horribly wrong with this book was confirmed. I put it down and resolved never to pick it up again. <br /> <br />Don't get me wrong, I can see the appeal. A Goddess-loving version of a timeless classic is a wonderful idea that I wish were more common! Sadly, it seems that that political and spiritual novelty is all this book really has going for it. Frankly, it has none of the love and loyalty that to me are the backbone of both great old epics and the new spiritual movements. Feminist women, Goddess-loving women, and New Age women are probably going to continue to like this book because of its concept, which can be truly revelatory and life-changing if it's your first exposure to it. But there are better modern retellings of the Arthurian story, as well as better modern Goddess-oriented epics--stories with more hope and inspiration than this. Enjoy this if it appeals to you, but remember, it's not the best--only the first. <br /> <br />In short, you'll probably either love this novel or be immensely turned off by it.  Check it out of the library. If you find the first couple of chapters enthralling, you should buy it, because you'll probably be one of those who do love it and are changed by it. If you begin to read it and feel a sense that dark, gloomy clouds are gathering inside you, and that you're reading a barbaric, hopeless soap opera, just stop and put the book away, because that darkness ain't gonna let up. You'll probably know ifyou're meant to read this or not, and more power to you either way. <br /> <br />BTW, if you strongly need historical or archaological/anthropological accuracy, stay the hell away from this. It's a fantasy, folks. Come on.  :)
B000063UR2|5.0|As long as unicorns roam the earth evil can never harm the pure of heart, and that is why the prince of Darkness has sent his most foulest goblins out into the very daylight he seeks to destroy forever to cut off the horns of the last two remaining. But when Jack (the forest boy, played by a very young Tom Cruise) takes Lily (a royal princess, played by the beautiful Mia Sara) to see them, she does the forbidden and touches these ancient creatures. Lily soon discovers it was she who unintentionally lured the unicorns into the goblin's trap; enabling them to shoot the poison stinger into one of the \\"beasts\\", as they call them, with a clear view. She vows to make things right again as the land becomes shrouded in a blanket of snow and tries to protect the last unicorn standing but is too frail to defend even herself. She then is captured, along with the unicorn, and taken back to the great tree where the wicked come to sacrifice. There the prince of Darkness yearns for a companion and tries to make Lily one of them by tempting her with jewels and power while Jack and his new friends Gump, a jealous sprite and some other nymphs, device a plan to save Lily, the unicorn, and the world before it's covered in eternal shadow.<br /><br />Legend wasn't too well received in theaters and was not a favorite among most critics but it has quickly become a cult classic with fantasy lovers like me. Considering the low budget director Ridley Scott was given in order to make this film in the mid-80s, I thought they did a wonderful job in bringing William Hjortsberg's dark fairytale to life, which was written specifically for the screen. I also felt the entire cast put on remarkable performances - especially Tim Curry who went through hell (pun intended) to look as devilish as he does here...<br /><br />Within this two-disc set is two versions of the film. One is the director's cut, as it was intended to be seen, and the other is the U.S. theatrical version, which I personally prefer, as do many others apparently. There are many extended scenes in the director's cut that were taken out of the U.S. release to trim down the overall running time but I felt the U.S. version simply flowed better. It also features a more dramatic score by Jerry Goldsmith instead of the more emotional score by Tangerine Dream and doesn't include the closing credits song \\"Is Your Love Strong Enough?\\" by Brian Ferry, ending the movie on a more magical note. But still, it was nice to see both versions and to compare the two. There's also a lot of bonus materials in the limited edition of Legend that many fans will be very grateful for.ers apparently. B00005JNEU|5.0|Ever since Peter Bogdanovich, in THE LAST PICTURE SHOW, provided a comic view of a small town's total involvement in the fortunes of a high school football team (remember the verbal abuse the locals heaped on Jeff Bridges and Timothy Bottoms when they lost the 'big game'?), Hollywood has attempted, with varying degrees of success, to make the 'definitive' small town/football film.<br /><br />Director Peter Berg has finally done it, with FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS!<br /><br />Based on H. G. Bissinger's best-selling tale of the 1988 season of  the Odessa (Texas) 'Permian Panthers', the film unflinchingly paints a vivid canvas of a school and community obsessed with winning, as football provides the only release from poverty and desperation. While the concept is reminiscent of Tom Cruise's earlier ALL THE RIGHT MOVES, Berg doesn't glamorize the hero or tie things up, neatly, at the climax; in real life, while victories are savored, they are, at best, a temporary 'high'...while defeats can drive rational people into irrational frenzies. The Panthers' fortunes are such a crutch to Odessa's emotional well-being, that each game becomes a narcotic 'fix' for the entire community...a situation potentially dangerous for the players, and their coaches.<br /><br />While Billy Bob Thornton has received the bulk of media attention, as the stern but fair head coach (with glowing reviews for BAD SANTA, and THE ALAMO, Thornton is having a career-defining year!), the film is really an ensemble work, with stand-out performances by Lucas Black, Derek Luke, Garrett Hedlund, and, surprisingly, singer Tim McGraw (as Hedlund's 'reliving past glories' father). The entire cast is exceptional, avoiding the easy pitfalls of simply playing stereotypes.<br /><br />At times brutal and gritty, at times nearly surrealistic, FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS refuses to fall into the clich&eacute;s that marred VARSITY BLUES and THE PROGRAM, eschewing the artsy but smug self-righteousness of Oliver Stone's ANY GIVEN SUNDAY, as well.<br /><br />This may well be the finest football film ever made...as well as one of the most honest portrayals of life in a small town.<br /><br />I will be surprised if it doesn't make most critics' 'Ten Best' lists, at year's end, and is a major Oscar contender.<br /><br />Peter Berg has gotten the formula right!UNDAY, as well. <br />  <br />This may well be the finest football film ever made...as well as one of the most honest portrayals of life in a small town. <br />  <br />I will be surprised if it doesn't make most critics' 'Ten Best' lists, at year's end, and is a major Oscar contender. <br />  <br />Peter Berg has gotten the formula right!     <br />

B000001FA4|4.0|The success of 1983's WAR had given U2 a very definite image in the minds of fans and critics - that of a fiery, politically charged and decidedly song-oriented band that compensated for its relative lack of musical sophistication with catchy hooks and instantly memorable melodies. So it came as more than a bit of a surprise to many people that the follow-up album, THE UNFORGETTABLE FIRE, was - and twenty years later remains - far and away U2's most impressionistic work, a dense and moody exploration of texture and atmosphere over riffery and songcraft with lots of mumbled, cut-and-paste lyrics which tend to augment rather than clarify the fogginess of their surrounding instrumental landscapes. Although the roots of nearly everything U2 would go on to do over the next two decades can be heard in some form somewhere on this album, THE UNFORGETTABLE FIRE is still a unique and at times downright perplexing entry in the group's catalogue.     Replacing founding producer Steve Lillywhite (who'd had no small hand in making them stars) with the big-signature team of Brian Eno and Daniel Lanois, the members of U2 make it clear right from the credits that they're after something new here. With two of the ten tracks eulogizing Martin Luther King, Jr., and others sporting titles such as \\"Fourth of July\\" and \\"Elvis Presley and America,\\" it's also obvious Bono and Company want to make a point of their growing interest in life across the Atlantic - although their music, at this stage, still has a decidedly European accent.     Having opened three consecutive albums with big, bombastic, arena-ready anthems, U2 here displays its newly broadened sonic pallette right off the bat with \\"A Sort of Homecoming,\\" a surging yet very nuanced power ballad of war and renewal with all the ambient stops pulled out as only Eno and Lanois can pull them, and only Larry Mullen's metronomic drumming to keep things from floating away altogether. Abstract it may be, but it's also quite effective, and leaves no question that this is a new U2 we're dealing with here. \\"Pride (In the Name of Love),\\" the album's only hit single, brings back the old, riff-driven U2, with a chiming, digitally delayed guitar track by the Edge that would define the band's sound for years to come. An homage to the slain Reverend King (who's also celebrated in the album's dreamy, drumless closer, \\"MLK\\"), the song actually sounds quite upbeat amidst the slow gloom around it. \\"Wire\\" is a lyrical mishmosh redeemed by a driving instrumental track which sounds like updated WAR material. The title track is almost certainly the strongest thing here, a painfully beautiful song of loss and resignation (about what, however, isn't quite clear) with sweeping synthesizers coloring one of Bono's most emotive performances. The singer is also outstanding on \\"Bad,\\" the lengthy elegy which highlights THE UNFORGETTABLE FIRE's second half, though once again the digital delay takes a fair amount of the spotlight as well.     The rest of the album consists of rather dark and hazy soundscapes which are only periodically tuneful in a conventional sense, and so only as strong or as weak as their various components - at times inspired and effecting, at others meandering and faceless. If one considers U2 a band worth listening to for its nuances alone (I do), there are enough good moments to make the trip worthwhile; if not, THE UNFORGETTABLE FIRE probably doesn't qualify as an essential purchase, especially since most of its best moments are included on the BEST OF 1980-1990 anthology. What is unquestionable, however, is that this album was a huge step forward for U2, one the band would build on to create some of the most important music of its era over the next few years.
B0000AMJED|5.0|Its hard to say if this one is better than the original as there are differences between the two. B00005JNEI|4.0|Yes, Michael Moore has an agenda. However, every documentary does. Believe it or not folks, but a documentary does not just show reality, it also interprets it. The point of a documentary is for those who see it to start making their own judgments. If you don't agree with Michael Moore's interpretation of the why's of the Iraq war, what is the right interpretation? Can you use the facts or find more facts to come up with a different interpretation? I would call that highly unlikely, but I would like to see the interpretation. This documentary set out to answer the question \\"Why is the US in Iraq?\\" I can tell you I have asked that question a lot and I found no good reason. Michael Moore has done the same thing, just to a larger audience. While you might disagree with his assessment that it was strictly for money, it is hard to support a different view after seeing this movie. You would be hard pressed to find any evidence linking Iraq and Al-Qaeda. Why? Because it doesn't exist. No matter how much Bush railed for a link, even he had to admit it wasn't there.<br /><br />How can you refute the 7 minutes of inactivity of Mr. Bush in the Florida classroom on 9/11? How can you refute the fact that planes were loaded up with Bin Laden relatives on 9/13? How can you call the \\"coalition of the willing\\" a coalition if it includes countries that send no troops? These are the facts folks. Michael Moore interpreted them to slam the Bush administration.
0140187650|4.0|Just a correction to anniecat45: <br />The phrase \\"banality of evil\\" can be found on pg. 252 of \\"Eichmann in Jerusalem\\". It is integral to Ms. Arendt's thesis and purpose, and was of course included in the book. The lowest a song on here could get is 10/10.    7.Orion (instrumental): In my opinion the greatest instrumental done by Metallica. Cliff Burton shows off his Jimi Hendrix like bass playing ability. All of Metallica's earliest instrumentals have Cliff Burton's excellent bass playing and this one is no exception. The rest of the band also does a stellar job with drums(Lars Ulrich), guitars(Kirk Hammett), and rhythm guitars(James Heitfeld).
